choices.text: Gynecologic oncology referral
Diagnostic laparoscopy with cystectomy
Expectant management with periodic surveillance if her CA125 level is normal.
Prescription of combination oral contraceptive pills to hasten cyst resolution.

questions.text: During the annual visit of a 56-year-old postmenopausal patient, you detect a right adnexal fullness during bimanual examination. Transvaginal sonography reveals a 3-cm thin-walled, unilocular cyst of the right ovary. She is asymptomatic. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial course of treatment?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Expectant management with periodic surveillance if her CA125 level is normal.

Explanation

Management of simple ovarian cysts as per age group

Pre-menopausal age group

  • ≤ 3cm diameter: normal anatomic finding
  • ≤ 5 cm diameter: No additional treatment required; just observation
  • 5-7 cm diameter: TVS in 6-12 months to document resolution, if persistent then further imaging (MRI) or surgical evaluation
  • > 7 cm: surgical (laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy

Postmenopausal

  • ≤ 1 cm: normal anaromic finding
  • 1-5cm: Ca125, if normal then repeat scan 6-12 months
  • > 5cm: Ca125, further imaging and to consider surgery

So in this patient as the cyst is ≤ 5 cm and she is post-menopausal, Ca 125 levels and repeat TVS after 6-12 months is recommended

Educational Objective:

Management of simple ovarian cysts as per age group

Pre-menopausal age group

  • ≤ 3cm diameter: normal anatomic finding
  • ≤ 5 cm diameter: No additional treatment required; just observation
  • 5-7 cm diameter: TVS in 6-12 months to document resolution, if persistent then further imaging (MRI) or surgical evaluation
  • > 7 cm: surgical (laparoscopic ovarian cystectomy

Postmenopausal

  • ≤ 1 cm: normal anaromic finding
  • 1-5cm: Ca125, if normal then repeat scan 6-12 months
  • > 5cm: Ca125, further imaging and to consider surgery

 

Ref: Page no 244, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Malignant ovarian neoplasm

questions.text: A 20-year-old nulligravida with a last menstrual period 5 days ago presents to the emergency department with generalized lower abdominal pain and fever. She reports a new sexual partner. Physical examination demonstrates guarding and bilateral adnexal fullness. Laboratory studies show leukocytosis, and transvaginal sonography reveals no visible ovaries, but bilateral adnexal masses as shown here. The diagnosis most consistent with these findings is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tuboovarian abscess

Explanation

  • This is a tubo-ovarian abscess which is seen in Pelvic Inflammatory Disease
  • It is an inflammatory mass involving the fallopian tube, ovary, and often surrounding structures.
  • If an ovary adheres to the fallopian tube, but is still visualized, it is called a tubo-ovarian complex.
  • A tuboovarian abscess results from a complete breakdown  ovarian and tubal architecture such that the separate structures are no longer identified.
  • Affected women usually have lower abdominal pain, fever, leukocytosis, and unilateral or bilateral adnexal masses.
  • Initial treatment of a tubo-ovarian abscess is by In patient antibiotic treatment
  • If no response to medical management observed, surgical management is considered

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Endometriosis: This commonly presents as dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, dull aching abdominal pain and infertility.  Examination will reveal a retroverted fixed uterus and nodularoty may be present. An ultrasound will show a chocolate cyst
  • Option B: Ovarian torsion will present as acute abdominal pain and this will increase and not be relieved by medication. A Doppler best diagnosis this condition where the classical whirlpool sign will be seen
  • Option D: Malignant ovarian neoplasm: This usually presents in the older age group with GI symptoms. Ultrasound will show a complex ovarian mass with solid areas, papillary projections, ascites and metastases

Educational Objective: 

  • A tubo-ovarian abscess, seen in Pelvic Inflammatory Disease is an inflammatory mass involving the fallopian tube, ovary, and often surrounding structures.
  • If an ovary adheres to the fallopian tube, but is still visualized, it is called a tubo-ovarian complex.
  • In contrast, a tuboovarian abscess results from a complete breakdown  ovarian and tubal architecture such that the separate structures are no longer identified.

Ref: Page 252, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Infundibulopelvic ligament
Ovarian ligament
Uterosacral ligament
Transverse cervical ligament

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman undergoes a total hysterectomy for painful fibroids. The ovaries will not be removed during the procedure. Which of the following ligaments must be preserved?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Infundibulopelvic  ligament

Explanation: 

  • The ovaries are held in place by the ovarian ligaments medially (attach ovary to the uterus) and the infundibulopelvic ligaments laterally (attach the ovary to the lateral pelvic wall)
  • In a hysterectomy if the ovaries are to be preserved, the ovarian  ligament is clamped, cut and ligated (i.e. infundibulopelvic ligament is preserved)
  • In a hysterectomy, if the ovaries are to be removed, the infundibulopelvic ligament is clamped, cut and ligated.
  • Hence to preseve the ovaries, the Infundibulopelvic ligament needs to be preserved

Other Options: 

  • Option B: Ovarian ligament: When the ovary needs to be preseved, the ovarian ligament is CUT, not preserved
  • Option C: Uterosacral ligaments: These are ligaments that support the uterus posteriorly and are not related to the ovaries
  • Option D: Transverse cervical ligaments: These provide lateral supports to the uterus

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The ovaries are held in place by the ovarian ligaments medially (attach ovary to the uterus) and the infundibulopelvic ligaments laterally (attach the ovary to the lateral pelvic wall)
  • In a hysterectomy if the ovaries are to be preserved, the ovarian  ligament is clamped, cut and ligated (i.e. infundibulopelvic ligament is preserved)
  • In a hysterectomy, if the ovaries are to be removed, the infundibulopelvic ligament is clamped, cut and ligated.


 

Ref: Page no 811, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology 15th edition

choices.text: Endometrial glands and stroma
Serous epithelial ovarian cancer

questions.text: A 28-year woman comes to the OPD due to discomfort due to urination in the last 3 months. Antibiotics for UTI were prescribed but her symptoms persisted. She has also noted increasing pain with passage of stools for 1 year particularly during menses. Bowel movements occur daily and are soft and not watery. Her symptoms have not improved with decrease in alcohol and caffeine and increased dietary fiber. The patient also has intermittent abdominal pain for 7 months. She is on no medication and has no surgical history. BMI is 19kg/m2. Abdominal exam reveals suprapubic tenderness. On pelvic exam, the uterus is immobile and retroverted. Rectovaginal exam reveals nodularity in the post cul de sac. Urine analysis is normal. Surgical biopsy of the nodules will most likely show?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Endometrial glands and stroma

Explanation:

  • This is endometriosis which is ectopic endometrium hence the histopathology of the nodules will show endometrial glands and stroma. 
  • Clues in this clinical question which point towards endometriosis are:
    • Complaints of painful defecation
    • Abdominal pain
    • Nodularity in the POD

 

Educational Objective:

  • Endometriosis presents as 5D’s
    • Dyspareunia
    • Dyschezia
    • Dull aching abdominal pain
    • Dysmenorrhea
    • Dysfertility (infertility)

 

​​​​​​​Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

choices.text: Endometrial glands and stroma
Endocervical glands and stroma

questions.text: With endometriosis, as shown here, which of the following is ectopically located?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Endometrial glands and stroma

Explanation

  • Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue (including glands and stroma) outside the uterus.

Educational Objective: 

  • Endometriosis is the presence of endometrial tissue (including glands and stroma) outside the uterus.
  • The most common site is the ovary where it presents as an endometriotic cyst (Chocolate cyst)

 

 

Ref: Page 253, DC Dutta Textbook of Gynecology 8th edition

questions.text: Which of the following theories is the most widely accepted as the cause of endometriosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Retrograde menstruation

Explanation

The definitive cause of endometriosis remains unknown, but theories have been proposed.

  • Retrograde menstruation through the fallopian tubes: Most favored theory

All the other options are less favoured theories. These include:

  • The stem cell theory: implicates undifferentiated endometrial cells that initially reside in the endometrium’s basalis layer. These cells differentiate into epithelial, stromal, and vascular cells as the endometrium is routinely regenerated each cycle. If displaced to an ectopic location, such as by retrograde menstruation, these stem cells may give rise to endometriosis
  • Aberrant lymphatic or vascular spread of endometrial tissue has also been implicated.
  • Coelomic metaplasia and suggests that the parietal peritoneum is pluripotent and can undergo metaplastic transformation to tissue histologically identical to normal endometrium.

Educational Objective: 

The most common theory of endometriosis is the theory of retrograde menstruation

 

Ref: Page no 231, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Persistence of endometriosis is directly dependent on which of the following hormones?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Estrogen

Explanation

Endometriosis is a hyperestrogenic state

Educational Objective: 

  • Endometriosis is a Hyperestrogenic state.
  • Estrogen facilitates the growth of the ectopic endometrial glands.
  • Endometriosis is an estrogen-dependent, chronic inflammatory disease with aberrant growth of ectopic endometrial tissue.
  • The disturbed molecular mechanisms in this disease are yet to be completely defined. However, suspected underpinnings include an environment estrogen dominance, estrogen dependence, and progesterone resistance within implants; inflammation; escape from immune clearance; local invasion and neurovascular development; and genetic predisposition.

Ref: Page no 233, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Solid with intra-cystic blood flow
Cystic with hyperechoic internal echoes
Solid with diffuse internal low level echoes
Cystic with diffuse internal low level echoes

questions.text: Sonographically, endometriomas are typically described as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cystic with diffuse internal low level echoes

Explanation

  • Endometriomas can be diagnosed by Trans vaginal sonography (TVS)
  • An endometrioma classically is cystic with homogeneous, low-level internal echoes, often described as “ground glass” echogenicity

Ultrasound image of an endometrioma

Educational Objective:

 

  • Endometriomas can be diagnosed by Trans vaginal sonography (TVS)
  • An endometrioma classically is cystic with homogeneous, low-level internal echoes, often described as “ground glass” echogenicity

Ultrasound image of an endometrioma

Ref: Page 263, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A 34-year woman presents to the OPD with progressively worsening dysmenorrhea. Her cycles are otherwise regular. On history she also reveals that she has been having painful intercourse which was never there before. She has an ultrasound done but has lost the report and shows you the images. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ovarian endometrioma

Explanation

  • This is an endometrioma (endometriotic cyst or chocolate cyst)
  • The patient is presenting with typical symptoms of endometriosis
  • The ultrasound shows the typical ground glass appearance of an endometrioma

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Ovarian torsion can be diagnosed by USG Doppler where the classical whirlpool sign is seen
  • Option B: Mature teratoma will appear on ultrasound as an ovarian mass with a solid nodule and acoustic shadowing on ultraosund
  • Option C: Tubo ovarian abscess will appear as a multi-locular complex adnexal mass with debris/ sepatations and an irregular thick wall on ultrasound

     

Educational Objective:

The classicail image of an ovarian endometrioma is as shown 

 

Ref: Page 263, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Laparoscopic ablation of lesions

questions.text: Women seeking immediate fertility and who suffer from endometriosis would most likely benefit from which of the following treatments?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Laparoscopic ablation of lesions

Explanation:

  • Treatment of endometriosis is by both medical or surgical management
  • If pain is prominent and conception is not currently desired, then medical therapy is typically selected.
    • Available agents include NSAIDs, OCPs, progestins, GnRH agents, and aromatase inhibitors.
    • In general, suitable starting regimens are NSAIDS alone or combined with oral contraceptive pills or with a progestin.
    • Although medical treatment improves pain, relapse rates are high with therapy discontinuation.
  • If infertility is the presenting symptom, then laparoscopic management should be considered (ablation/ excision of endometriotic implants)

 

Ref: Page 265, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Cyst wall ablation
None of the above

questions.text: For surgical treatment of endometriomas, which of the following approaches is superior?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cystectomy

Explanation

  • Endometriomas are typically treated surgically to exclude malignancy or treat associated pain.
  • Cystectomy lowers endometrioma recurrence rates and pain symptoms and improves subsequent spontaneous pregnancy rates
  • During surgery, ideally normal ovarian tissue is preserved as much as possible

 

Ref: Page no 269, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A 25-year woman is undergoing a diagnostic laparoscopy for unexplained infertility. The following is seen. What is the best management option?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ablation of the lesions

 

Explanation

 

  • The black-brown lesions seen on the surface of the ovary are endometriotic lesions
  • Endometriotic lesions like these require to be ablated so that the ectopic endometrium is destroyed
  • Ovarian tissue should not be damaged

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ovarian cystectomy: Done for endometrioma, not for surface lesions. there are no endometrioma to be removed in this case

 

Option C. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling: It is not a treatment for endometriosis. It is used for infertility management in PCOS

 

Option D. Laparoscopic adhesiolysis: There are no adhesions in the image. no requirement of adhesiolysis.

 

Ref: Page no 264, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition
